recipes.title: Cajun Blackened Pacific Salmon
steps: Mix Cajun seasoning, paprika, garlic powder, onion powder, and cayenne in a bowl.
Pat salmon fillets dry and coat both sides with the spice mixture.
Heat a cast-iron skillet over high heat until very hot.
Add butter and let it melt, then add salmon fillets skin-side up.
Cook for 3-4 minutes until blackened, then flip and cook 3-4 minutes more.
Serve immediately with lemon wedges and fresh parsley.
recipes.culturalBackground: Cajun cuisine originates from Louisiana, combining French, Spanish, and African influences. Blackening is a cooking technique that creates a flavorful crust.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with rice pilaf, steamed vegetables, or a fresh green salad. Pairs well with a crisp white wine.

recipes.title: Teriyaki Pacific Salmon
steps: Mix soy sauce, mirin, sake, brown sugar, ginger, and garlic in a bowl to make teriyaki sauce.
Marinate salmon fillets in half the sauce for 30 minutes.
Heat a pan over medium heat and cook salmon skin-side down for 4-5 minutes.
Flip and cook for 3-4 minutes, then add remaining teriyaki sauce.
Simmer until sauce thickens and glazes the salmon.
Garnish with green onions and sesame seeds.
recipes.culturalBackground: Teriyaki is a Japanese cooking technique where foods are grilled or broiled with a glaze of soy sauce, mirin, and sugar. It's one of Japan's most popular cooking methods.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with steamed rice, miso soup, and pickled vegetables. Perfect for a traditional Japanese meal.

recipes.title: Spanish Grilled Mackerel with Garlic and Paprika
steps: Score the mackerel on both sides with diagonal cuts.
Mix garlic, paprika, olive oil, lemon juice, salt, and pepper in a bowl.
Rub the mixture inside and outside the fish.
Preheat grill to medium-high heat.
Grill mackerel for 5-6 minutes per side until skin is crispy.
Garnish with parsley and serve with lemon wedges.
recipes.culturalBackground: Grilled fish is a staple of Spanish coastal cuisine, especially in regions like Galicia and Andalusia. The combination of garlic and paprika is quintessentially Spanish.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with roasted potatoes, grilled vegetables, or a simple green salad. Pair with a crisp Spanish white wine.

recipes.title: Italian Grilled Swordfish with Lemon and Herbs
steps: Mix olive oil, garlic, oregano, basil, lemon zest, and juice in a bowl.
Season swordfish steaks with salt and pepper, then coat with the herb mixture.
Let marinate for 20 minutes.
Preheat grill to medium-high heat.
Grill swordfish for 4-5 minutes per side until opaque and slightly charred.
Serve with lemon slices and drizzle with remaining marinade.
recipes.culturalBackground: Swordfish is a favorite in Italian coastal regions, especially Sicily. The simple preparation with fresh herbs and lemon highlights the fish's natural flavor.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with risotto, grilled vegetables, or a caprese salad. Pair with a light Italian white wine like Pinot Grigio.

recipes.title: Norwegian Pickled Herring
steps: Clean and fillet the herring, removing bones.
Bring vinegar, sugar, water, peppercorns, and bay leaves to a boil.
Let the pickling liquid cool completely.
Layer herring fillets and onion slices in a glass jar.
Pour cooled pickling liquid over the herring.
Add dill sprigs and refrigerate for at least 24 hours before serving.
recipes.culturalBackground: Pickled herring is a traditional Norwegian dish, often served during holidays and celebrations. It's a preservation method that dates back centuries.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve on dark rye bread with sour cream, hard-boiled eggs, and pickled beets. Traditional Norwegian breakfast or appetizer.

recipes.title: Sinigang na Isda (Filipino Sour Fish Soup)
ingredients: 2 lbs skipjack tuna, cut into steaks
1 cup string beans, cut into 2-inch pieces
steps: Bring water to a boil in a large pot.
Add tomato and onion, simmer for 5 minutes.
Add sinigang mix and stir until dissolved.
Add radish and cook for 3 minutes.
Add fish steaks and cook for 5-7 minutes.
Add string beans and chilies, cook for 2 minutes.
Add water spinach and cook for 1 minute.
Season with fish sauce, salt, and pepper. Serve hot.
recipes.culturalBackground: Sinigang is one of the most popular dishes in the Philippines, known for its sour and savory flavor. The tamarind-based soup is a comfort food for many Filipinos.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with steamed rice. The sour soup is perfect for any meal and pairs well with fried fish or grilled dishes.

recipes.title: Inihaw na Isda (Grilled Fish in Banana Leaves)
ingredients: 2 lbs skipjack tuna, whole or filleted
steps: Mix calamansi juice, soy sauce, garlic, ginger, salt, and pepper to make marinade.
Marinate fish for 30 minutes.
Place fish on banana leaves, add lemongrass if using.
Wrap tightly in banana leaves and secure with string.
Grill over medium heat for 15-20 minutes, turning occasionally.
Serve in the banana leaf wrapper.
recipes.culturalBackground: Inihaw (grilled) is a popular Filipino cooking method. Wrapping fish in banana leaves keeps it moist and adds a subtle, earthy flavor.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with steamed rice, atchara (pickled papaya), and a dipping sauce of soy sauce, calamansi, and chili.

recipes.title: Baja-Style Mahi-Mahi Tacos
steps: Mix flour, beer, baking powder, salt, and pepper to make batter.
Heat oil to 350°F in a deep pan.
Dip fish strips in batter and fry until golden brown (3-4 minutes).
Drain on paper towels.
Warm tortillas and fill with fish, cabbage, pico de gallo.
Top with chipotle mayo, cilantro, and lime juice.
recipes.culturalBackground: Baja-style fish tacos originated in Baja California, Mexico. The beer-battered fish and fresh toppings create a perfect balance of textures and flavors.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve immediately while hot. Perfect for a casual meal with Mexican rice and beans.

recipes.title: Veracruz-Style Baked Mahi-Mahi
steps: Preheat oven to 375°F.
Heat olive oil in a large oven-safe pan.
Sauté onion and garlic until soft.
Add tomatoes, olives, capers, and jalapeños. Cook for 5 minutes.
Add white wine and bring to a simmer.
Place fish fillets on top of the sauce.
Bake for 15-20 minutes until fish is flaky.
Garnish with fresh oregano.
recipes.culturalBackground: Pescado a la Veracruzana is a classic Mexican dish from Veracruz, combining Spanish and indigenous flavors. The tomato-based sauce with olives and capers is distinctive.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with white rice, black beans, and warm tortillas. A refreshing Mexican beer pairs perfectly.

recipes.title: Maple-Glazed Pacific Salmon
steps: Mix maple syrup, mustard, soy sauce, garlic, and thyme in a bowl.
Season salmon with salt and pepper.
Brush fillets with half the glaze.
Bake at 400°F for 12-15 minutes.
Brush with remaining glaze and broil for 2 minutes.
Serve with lemon wedges.
recipes.culturalBackground: Maple syrup is a quintessential Canadian ingredient. This recipe combines the sweetness of maple with the richness of salmon, creating a uniquely Canadian flavor profile.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with roasted vegetables and wild rice. Perfect for a Canadian dinner party.

recipes.title: Thai Yellowfin Tuna Curry
ingredients: 1.5 lbs yellowfin tuna, cut into chunks
steps: Heat a wok and fry curry paste until fragrant.
Add half the coconut milk and stir until oil separates.
Add remaining coconut milk, fish sauce, and palm sugar.
Add lime leaves and bring to a simmer.
Add tuna chunks and bell pepper, cook for 5-7 minutes.
Stir in basil and chilies.
Finish with lime juice and serve.
recipes.culturalBackground: Thai curries are known for their balance of sweet, sour, salty, and spicy flavors. This dish showcases the aromatic complexity of Thai cuisine.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with jasmine rice and a side of pickled vegetables. The curry is best enjoyed hot.

recipes.title: Japanese Grilled Mackerel (Saba Shioyaki)
steps: Salt mackerel fillets generously and let sit for 30 minutes.
Rinse off salt and pat dry.
Score the skin side with diagonal cuts.
Grill skin-side down over medium heat for 4-5 minutes.
Flip and grill for 3-4 minutes until crispy.
Serve with grated daikon, soy sauce, and lemon.
recipes.culturalBackground: Saba shioyaki is a classic Japanese dish, often served for breakfast. The simple salt-grilling method brings out the mackerel's natural oils and flavor.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with steamed rice, miso soup, and pickled vegetables. Traditional Japanese breakfast or lunch.

recipes.title: Greek Grilled Swordfish with Oregano
steps: Mix olive oil, oregano, garlic, and lemon juice for marinade.
Marinate swordfish for 1 hour.
Preheat grill to medium-high.
Grill swordfish for 5-6 minutes per side.
Season with salt and pepper.
Garnish with parsley and serve with lemon.
recipes.culturalBackground: Greek cuisine emphasizes fresh ingredients and simple preparations. This dish showcases the Mediterranean tradition of grilling fish with herbs and olive oil.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with Greek salad, roasted potatoes, and tzatziki. Pair with a crisp Greek white wine.

recipes.title: British Herring in Oatmeal
steps: Season herring fillets with salt and pepper.
Coat fillets in oatmeal, pressing gently.
Heat butter in a pan over medium heat.
Fry herring skin-side down for 4-5 minutes.
Flip and cook for 3-4 minutes until golden.
Serve with lemon and parsley.
recipes.culturalBackground: Herring in oatmeal is a traditional Scottish dish. The oatmeal creates a crispy coating that complements the rich flavor of the herring.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with mashed potatoes and green vegetables. A classic British pub meal.

recipes.title: Indonesian Tuna Rendang
ingredients: 2 lbs skipjack tuna, cut into chunks
steps: Heat a pan and fry rendang paste until fragrant.
Add coconut milk and bring to a boil.
Add lemongrass and lime leaves.
Add tuna chunks and simmer on low heat for 1 hour.
Stir occasionally until sauce thickens and oil separates.
Season with salt, sugar, and tamarind.
Cook until dry and serve.
recipes.culturalBackground: Rendang is a slow-cooked curry from West Sumatra, Indonesia. It's traditionally made with beef, but fish rendang is a coastal variation.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with steamed rice and sambal. The rich, spicy flavor is best enjoyed with plain rice.

recipes.title: Australian Grilled Barramundi with Lemon Myrtle
steps: Mix lemon myrtle, olive oil, salt, and pepper.
Coat barramundi fillets with the mixture.
Preheat grill to medium-high.
Grill fillets skin-side down for 5 minutes.
Flip and grill for 4-5 minutes until flaky.
Garnish with dill and serve with lemon.
recipes.culturalBackground: Barramundi is native to Australia and is a favorite in Australian cuisine. Lemon myrtle is a native Australian herb with a strong citrus flavor.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with roasted sweet potatoes and a fresh salad. Perfect for an Australian barbecue.

recipes.title: French Provençal Baked Pollock
steps: Preheat oven to 375°F.
Heat olive oil and sauté onion and garlic.
Add tomatoes, wine, and herbs. Simmer for 10 minutes.
Place fish in a baking dish and pour sauce over.
Add olives and bake for 20 minutes.
Serve hot.
recipes.culturalBackground: Provençal cuisine from the south of France emphasizes fresh vegetables, herbs, and olive oil. This dish captures the essence of Mediterranean French cooking.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with crusty bread and a green salad. Pair with a Provençal rosé wine.

recipes.title: American Grilled King Mackerel with Herbs
steps: Mix herbs, olive oil, lemon zest, and juice.
Season fish with salt and pepper.
Coat with herb mixture.
Grill over medium heat for 5-6 minutes per side.
Serve immediately.
recipes.culturalBackground: Grilled fish with fresh herbs is a popular American coastal dish, especially in the Southeast. The simple preparation highlights the fish's natural flavor.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with coleslaw, corn on the cob, or a fresh green salad. Perfect for summer grilling.

recipes.title: Hawaiian Poke-Style Wahoo
steps: Mix soy sauce, sesame oil, and rice vinegar.
Toss wahoo cubes with the sauce.
Add green onions and macadamia nuts.
Marinate for 30 minutes in refrigerator.
Serve chilled with sesame seeds and seaweed.
recipes.culturalBackground: Poke is a traditional Hawaiian dish of raw fish marinated in soy sauce and sesame oil. This recipe adapts the classic poke for wahoo.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve over rice or as an appetizer. Best enjoyed fresh and cold.

recipes.title: Italian Spaghetti with Anchovies and Garlic
steps: Cook spaghetti according to package directions.
Heat olive oil in a large pan.
Add garlic and cook until golden.
Add anchovies and mash with a fork.
Add red pepper flakes.
Toss with cooked pasta.
Garnish with parsley and lemon zest.
Serve with Parmesan if desired.
recipes.culturalBackground: Spaghetti aglio e olio with anchovies is a classic Italian dish from Naples. The anchovies dissolve into the oil, creating a rich, umami flavor.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with a simple green salad and crusty bread. A light Italian white wine complements this dish perfectly.

recipes.title: Lebanese Sayadieh with Sea Bream
ingredients: 1 whole sea bream (2-3 lbs), cleaned and scaled
steps: Heat olive oil in a large pot and caramelize onions until golden brown (15-20 minutes).
Add cumin, coriander, and turmeric to the onions and toast for 1 minute.
Add rice and stir to coat with spices.
Add fish stock, bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer covered for 15 minutes.
Season sea bream with salt and pepper, then pan-fry in olive oil until crispy (5-6 minutes per side).
Toast pine nuts and almonds separately until golden.
Fluff rice and serve on a platter, top with fish, and garnish with toasted nuts and parsley.
Serve with lemon wedges.
recipes.culturalBackground: Sayadieh is one of Lebanon's most beloved fish dishes. The name means 'fisherman's dish' and features caramelized onions, spiced rice, and crispy fried fish. It's a staple in coastal Lebanese cuisine.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve family-style on a large platter. Traditionally accompanied by a fresh green salad, pickled vegetables (mouneh), and tahini sauce. Perfect for a Lebanese feast.

recipes.title: Grilled Seabass with Tahini Sauce (Samak Meshwi)
steps: Mix tahini, lemon juice, garlic, water, cumin, salt, and pepper to make tahini sauce. Adjust consistency with water if needed.
Season seabass fillets with salt, pepper, and olive oil.
Preheat grill to medium-high heat.
Grill seabass skin-side down for 4-5 minutes, then flip and grill for 3-4 minutes until flaky.
Arrange fish on a platter and drizzle with tahini sauce.
Garnish with parsley, sumac, and serve with lemon wedges.
recipes.culturalBackground: Grilled fish with tahini sauce is a classic Lebanese coastal dish. The creamy tahini complements the delicate flavor of seabass, and sumac adds a tangy, lemony note typical of Levantine cuisine.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with fattoush salad, hummus, and warm pita bread. A crisp Lebanese white wine or arak pairs beautifully with this dish.

recipes.title: Pan-Fried Red Mullet with Garlic and Coriander (Sultan Ibrahim)
steps: Season red mullet with salt and pepper, then dust lightly with flour.
Heat olive oil in a large pan over medium-high heat.
Pan-fry mullet for 3-4 minutes per side until golden and crispy.
Remove fish and set aside on a platter.
In the same pan, add more olive oil if needed and sauté garlic until golden.
Add fresh coriander, parsley, ground coriander, and lemon juice.
Cook for 1 minute, then pour the sauce over the fish.
Serve immediately with lemon wedges.
recipes.culturalBackground: Red mullet, known as 'Sultan Ibrahim' in Lebanon, is highly prized for its delicate flavor. This simple preparation with garlic and coriander is a traditional Lebanese way of cooking this fish, highlighting its natural sweetness.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with Lebanese rice pilaf, fattoush salad, and warm pita bread. The fish is best eaten whole, picking the meat from the bones.

recipes.title: Lebanese Stuffed Sardines (Sardines Mahshi)
ingredients: 2 lbs fresh sardines, cleaned and butterflied
steps: Soak bulgur in warm water for 20 minutes, then drain and squeeze out excess water.
Sauté onion in olive oil until soft, then add pine nuts and toast until golden.
Mix bulgur with onion, pine nuts, parsley, mint, allspice, cinnamon, salt, and pepper.
Stuff each sardine with the bulgur mixture and close.
Arrange stuffed sardines in a baking dish, drizzle with olive oil.
Bake at 375°F for 20-25 minutes until fish is cooked through.
Serve hot with tahini sauce and lemon wedges.
recipes.culturalBackground: Stuffed sardines are a traditional Lebanese dish, especially popular in coastal areas. The bulgur stuffing with herbs and spices is a classic Levantine preparation, and this dish is often served during special occasions.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve as a main course with a fresh salad and pickled vegetables. This dish is perfect for sharing and is often part of a mezze spread.

recipes.title: Lebanese Baked Dentex with Tomatoes and Herbs
steps: Preheat oven to 400°F.
Make diagonal cuts on both sides of the fish.
Mix olive oil, garlic, parsley, cilantro, thyme, sumac, salt, and pepper.
Rub the herb mixture inside and outside the fish, including the cuts.
Layer tomatoes and onions in a baking dish.
Place fish on top of the vegetables and arrange lemon slices on the fish.
Bake for 30-35 minutes until fish is flaky and vegetables are tender.
Garnish with fresh herbs and pomegranate seeds if using.
recipes.culturalBackground: Baked fish with tomatoes and herbs is a classic Lebanese preparation, especially for larger fish like dentex. The combination of fresh herbs, sumac, and tomatoes creates a vibrant, Mediterranean flavor profile.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with Lebanese rice, roasted vegetables, and a side of tahini. Perfect for a family dinner or special occasion.

recipes.title: Lebanese Grilled Mackerel with Za'atar
steps: Mix za'atar, olive oil, lemon juice, and garlic to make marinade.
Marinate mackerel fillets for 30 minutes.
Preheat grill to medium-high.
Grill mackerel skin-side down for 5 minutes, then flip and grill for 4 minutes.
Garnish with parsley and sumac.
Serve with lemon wedges.
recipes.culturalBackground: Za'atar is a quintessential Lebanese spice blend of thyme, sumac, and sesame seeds. Grilling mackerel with za'atar is a popular Lebanese coastal preparation that brings out the fish's rich flavor.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with tabbouleh, hummus, and warm pita bread. A refreshing Lebanese salad completes the meal.

recipes.title: Thai Tuna Green Curry
ingredients: 1.5 lbs skipjack tuna, cut into chunks
steps: Fry green curry paste in a wok until fragrant.
Add half the coconut milk and cook until oil separates.
Add remaining coconut milk, fish sauce, and palm sugar.
Add eggplant and cook for 5 minutes.
Add tuna chunks and cook for 5-7 minutes.
Stir in basil, chilies, and lime leaves.
Finish with lime juice and serve.
recipes.culturalBackground: Green curry is one of Thailand's most popular dishes, known for its balance of spicy, sweet, and creamy flavors. This version with tuna showcases the versatility of Thai curry.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with jasmine rice and a side of pickled vegetables. The curry is best enjoyed hot.

recipes.title: Brazilian Moqueca de Peixe
steps: Marinate fish in lime juice, salt, and pepper for 30 minutes.
In a large pot, layer onions, tomatoes, and bell pepper.
Add fish chunks on top.
Pour coconut milk and dendê oil over everything.
Simmer for 20 minutes until fish is cooked.
Garnish with cilantro and serve.
recipes.culturalBackground: Moqueca is a traditional Brazilian fish stew from Bahia, combining African, Portuguese, and indigenous influences. The dendê oil gives it a distinctive orange color and rich flavor.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with white rice and farofa. A refreshing caipirinha complements this dish perfectly.

recipes.title: Thai Steamed Barramundi with Lime and Chili
steps: Make diagonal cuts on both sides of the fish.
Mix lime juice, chilies, garlic, fish sauce, and palm sugar for sauce.
Steam fish for 15-20 minutes until cooked.
Pour sauce over fish and garnish with herbs and lime slices.
Serve immediately.
recipes.culturalBackground: Steamed fish with lime and chili is a classic Thai preparation that highlights the fish's natural flavor. The spicy, sour sauce is characteristic of Thai cuisine.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with steamed jasmine rice and a side of stir-fried vegetables. The dish is light and refreshing.

recipes.title: British Fish and Chips with Pollock
steps: Cut potatoes into chips and fry until golden.
Mix flour, beer, baking powder, salt, and pepper for batter.
Heat oil to 350°F.
Dip pollock in batter and fry until golden (5-6 minutes).
Serve with chips, vinegar, and tartar sauce.
recipes.culturalBackground: Fish and chips is Britain's most iconic dish, traditionally made with cod or haddock. Using pollock is a sustainable alternative that maintains the classic flavor.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve wrapped in paper with malt vinegar and tartar sauce. A classic British pub meal.

recipes.title: Greek Baked Seabass with Potatoes
steps: Preheat oven to 400°F.
Layer potatoes in a baking dish, drizzle with olive oil.
Bake potatoes for 20 minutes.
Place fish on potatoes, season with garlic, lemon, oregano, salt, and pepper.
Bake for 25 minutes until fish is flaky.
Serve hot.
recipes.culturalBackground: Baked fish with potatoes is a traditional Greek dish, especially popular in coastal regions. The simple preparation with olive oil and lemon is quintessentially Mediterranean.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with a Greek salad and crusty bread. A crisp Greek white wine pairs perfectly.

recipes.title: Greek Grilled Red Mullet
steps: Mix olive oil, garlic, lemon juice, oregano, salt, and pepper.
Marinate mullet for 30 minutes.
Grill over medium heat for 4-5 minutes per side.
Serve with lemon wedges.
recipes.culturalBackground: Grilled red mullet is a favorite in Greek coastal cuisine. The fish is often grilled whole and served simply with lemon and herbs.
recipes.servingSuggestions: Serve with horiatiki salad and roasted vegetables. Perfect for a Greek summer meal.
